temperament_observations: Daily routines: Wakes up and immediately starts playing Lego

concerns.parent_narrative: קושי עם מעברים, בעיקר בבוקר. Refuses to stop playing Lego to get dressed. Escalates to tantrums, crying, and throwing things. Happens every day

hypotheses.theory: Transition difficulties are likely driven by a high need for cognitive control and predictability
hypotheses.source_details: Connection between morning struggles and general difficulty with sudden changes in a 'planner' child
questions_to_explore: Does preparation/warning help with the changes?
How does he react if he is the one initiating the change?

evidence.content: likes to know what will happen

Child has intense tantrums (throwing things) specifically when asked to stop a structured, preferred activity (Lego) to transition to a daily task. (The struggle is specifically about stopping a self-controlled, structured activity (Lego) for an external demand, reinforcing the need for control/predictability hypothesis.)

Parent reports that advance warnings ('5 minutes') help sometimes, but not always. Some days meltdowns occur even with warnings. (The fact that predictability (warnings) helps at all supports the theory that the difficulty is related to cognitive control and preparation, though the inconsistency suggests other factors (like regulation state) also play a role.)

patterns.theme: Need for predictability and difficulty with flexibility
patterns.description: Observations: struggles with morning transitions; struggles with sudden changes; likes to know what is going to happen
Observations: Won't leave Lego game; Tantrums when interrupted; Morning transition is the hardest

journal_entries.content: He wakes up and starts playing Lego. When I tell him it's time to dress, he simply won't leave the game. It reaches tantrums, crying, sometimes throwing things.
journal_entries.context: Parent describing the specific difficulty with morning transitions
